I am blissfully unaware of any "inertia*, "terminal
conditions", or "frozen thinking" in this office. I am
painfully aware of the lack of duplicating equipment. It
is well past time that such equipment were installed and
operating. We have chosen to go slowly, Jim perhaps more
than I, for the simple reason that a sum of money of this
size is not apt to be available more than once. We have,
therefore, felt it wise to get the best equipment for the
job—for whatever we get, we are stuck with>*for a long
time. *
I have not taken a survey on the subject—such could be
done very easily, of course—but from the unsolicited comments
that have come in here the majority of the stations favor
the package system over the old method. It allows them the
maximum flexibility in scheduling. We are currently mailing
fifteen programs. On the old basis this would mean fifteen
station groupings and fifteen mailing schedules. The reduction
in red tape, paper work, and administrative detail was not
intended to lighten our work week here in the office but to
assist the stations in getting the maximum service with a
minimum of failures and confusion. After careful consideration
of the problem of providing maximum program service to more
than sixty stations, we decided that the package method
was the only answer until all stations could be handled on an
individual and separate basis.
2. Programming policies. The kinds, the quantities, and
the purposes of programs offered by the network represent a
highly complicated problem. It is not, in ray opinion, an
open and shut case. There are many possible asnwers to the
problem, and it seems to me that either the board or a
committee, or both, should consider the possibilities over ^
period of a year or two before finally settling on permanent
program policy. This als°requires a rather careful study
of the member station^to determine their needs, and equally
as important, their desires. But, this is no help in the
immediate problem.
